'''Shelby Lynne''' (born '''Shelby Lynn Moorer''', October 22, 1968) is an American singer and [[songwriter]] and the older sister of singer-songwriter [[Allison Moorer]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2010/12/15/132082946/shelby-lynne-and-allison-moorer-musical-sisters|title=Shelby Lynne And Allison Moorer: Musical Sisters|website=NPR.org|access-date=2018-04-04|archive-date=2017-09-20|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170920182902/http://www.npr.org/2010/12/15/132082946/shelby-lynne-and-allison-moorer-musical-sisters|url-status=live}}</ref> The success of her [[pop rock]] album ''[[I Am Shelby Lynne]]'' (1999) led to her winning the [[Grammy Award for Best New Artist]], despite it being her sixth studio album. She released a [[Dusty Springfield]] tribute album called ''[[Just a Little Lovin' (Shelby Lynne album)|Just a Little Lovin']]'' in 2008. Since then she has started her own independent record label, called Everso Records, and released six albums: ''[[Tears, Lies and Alibis]]''; ''[[Merry Christmas (Shelby Lynne album)|Merry Christmas]]''; ''[[Revelation Road]]''; ''Thanks'';<ref>{{Citation |title=Shelby Lynne - Thanks Album Reviews, Songs & More {{!}} AllMusic |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/thanks-mw0002585789 |access-date=2023-03-29 |language=en |archive-date=2023-03-29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230329174922/https://www.allmusic.com/album/thanks-mw0002585789 |url-status=live }}</ref> ''[[I Can't Imagine (album)|I Can't Imagine]]''; and ''[[Shelby Lynne (album)|Shelby Lynne]]''. Lynne is also known for her distinctive [[contralto]] voice.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/temptation-mw0000098901| title=Shelby Lynne - Temptation review| work=Allmusic| year=1993| access-date=20 August 2012| first=Thom| last=Jurek| archive-date=5 November 2012| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105020025/http://www.allmusic.com/album/temptation-mw0000098901| url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url = http://articles.nydailynews.com/2011-10-18/entertainment/30311678_1_shelby-lynne-revelation-road-dusty-springfield-s| archive-url = https://archive.today/20130104064232/http://articles.nydailynews.com/2011-10-18/entertainment/30311678_1_shelby-lynne-revelation-road-dusty-springfield-s| url-status = dead| archive-date = January 4, 2013| title = 'Revelation Road' review: Shelby Lynne | work=New York Daily News| date=18 October 2011| access-date=20 August 2012| first=Jim| last=Farber}}</ref>

==Early life==
Shelby Lynne was born in [[Quantico, Virginia]], and raised in [[Jackson, Alabama]], then [[Mobile, Alabama|Mobile]], where she attended [[Theodore High School]]. Music was an important part of the Moorer family. Her father was a local bandleader and her mother a harmony-singing teacher; as children, she and her younger sister [[Allison Moorer|Allison]] — later a country recording artist in her own right — sometimes joined their parents on-stage to sing along. However, Lynne's father was a violent alcoholic who abused his wife. In 1985, her mother fled with the two girls to Mobile. Her father soon discovered their whereabouts. In 1986, when Lynne was 17 and her sister was 14, he fatally shot her mother in the family's driveway. He then turned the gun on himself while his daughters were in the house.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.npr.org/2010/12/15/132082946/shelby-lynne-and-allison-moorer-musical-sisters | title=Shelby Lynne and Allison Moorer: Musical Sisters | publisher=NPR | date=December 15, 2010 | access-date=April 4, 2018 | archive-date=September 20, 2017 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170920182902/http://www.npr.org/2010/12/15/132082946/shelby-lynne-and-allison-moorer-musical-sisters | url-status=live }}</ref>

==Career==
===Early years===
Lynne appeared on [[The Nashville Network|TNN]]'s country music show ''[[Nashville Now]]'' in 1987. She soon landed a recording contract with [[Epic Records]]. Her first recording for Epic was a duet with [[George Jones]], "If I Could Bottle This Up", which became a top-50 hit in 1988.  Epic teamed Lynne with producer [[Billy Sherrill]] for her 1989 debut album ''[[Sunrise (Shelby Lynne album)|Sunrise]]''. The follow-up, 1990's ''[[Tough All Over (Shelby Lynne album)|Tough All Over]]'', took more of a mainstream country direction, and 1991's ''[[Soft Talk]]'' found Lynne moving into slick [[country pop]].

Lynne placed several songs on the country charts during this period, but none managed to break into the top 20. Critics generally regarded her as a promising talent, and she won the [[Academy of Country Music Award for New Female Artist of the Year|Academy of Country Music Award for Top New Female Vocalist]] in 1991, beating the other two nominees [[Carlene Carter]] and [[Matraca Berg]].

However, she was tiring of the lack of control she was afforded over her image and musical direction. She split from Epic and signed with the smaller [[Morgan Creek Productions|Morgan Creek]] label, debuting with 1993's ''[[Temptation (Shelby Lynne album)|Temptation]]'', an exercise in [[Bob Wills]]-style [[Western swing]] and [[big band]] jazz. The label folded not long after, and she moved on to [[Magnatone]] for 1995's ''[[Restless (Shelby Lynne album)|Restless]]'', which marked a return to contemporary-style country. Afterward, Lynne disappeared from recording for several years.  One notable project that she assisted on was Vince Gill's 1996 ''High Lonesome Sound'' album, where she provided background, harmony vocals on the song "[[You and You Alone (song)|You And You Alone]]".
Vince Gill and Shelby Lynne performed the song at the 1997 CMA awards show.

===Breakthrough===
In 1998, Lynne moved to [[Palm Springs, California]].<ref>{{cite magazine | url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,996707,00.html | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101122105431/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,996707,00.html | url-status=dead | archive-date=November 22, 2010 | title=Music: Blows Against The Empire | author=Thigpen, David E. | magazine=TIME | date=April 24, 2000}}</ref> For her next record, she worked with producer and songwriter [[Bill Bottrell]]. The result was the confessional and eclectic [[pop rock]] and [[blues]]-influenced album ''[[I Am Shelby Lynne]]''. "That album came from the most vulnerable, desperate place," she recalled years later. "I think about it every day."<ref name="dusty trail">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/13/magazine/13Lynne-t.html | title=Shelby Lynne's Dusty Trail | author=Hoerburger, Rob | newspaper=The New York Times | date=January 13, 2008 | access-date=February 23, 2017 | archive-date=November 9, 2016 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161109135632/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/13/magazine/13Lynne-t.html | url-status=live }}</ref> Island Def Jam released the album in the U.K. during the fall of 1999 and then in the U.S. the following year, to wide critical acclaim.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-2001-feb-18-ca-26778-story.html | title=She Had Such High Hopes | author=Hilburn, Robert | newspaper=Los Angeles Times | date=February 18, 2001 | access-date=August 8, 2010 | archive-date=October 26, 2012 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121026001455/http://articles.latimes.com/2001/feb/18/entertainment/ca-26778 | url-status=live }}</ref> At the [[43rd Grammy Awards]], held on February 21, 2001, she won the award for [[Grammy Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]]. "Thirteen years and six albums to get here," said Lynne during her acceptance speech.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://edition.cnn.com/2001/SHOWBIZ/Music/02/21/grammy.night.04/ | title=Steely Dan, Faith Hill, Eminem, U2 each win 3 Grammys | author=Allen, Jamie | publisher=CNN | date=February 22, 2001 | access-date=August 3, 2010 | archive-date=October 21, 2012 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021200637/http://edition.cnn.com/2001/SHOWBIZ/Music/02/21/grammy.night.04/ | url-status=live }}</ref> One of the songs, "Dreamsome", also appeared on the soundtrack of the film ''[[Bridget Jones's Diary (film)|Bridget Jones's Diary]]''.

Her 2001 follow-up album ''[[Love, Shelby]]'' was produced by [[Glen Ballard]] and featured a slicker, more pop-influenced sound. The album received mixed reviews.

Lynne took a more low-key approach on her next effort. ''[[Identity Crisis (Shelby Lynne album)|Identity Crisis]]'' was self-produced, recorded largely in her home studio and with few additional musicians. Many of the 12 tracks focused on dark themes, but there were also lighter songs such as "One With the Sun" (inspired by a conversation she had with [[Willie Nelson]]).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://archives.nodepression.com/2003/09/this-years-model/ | title=This year's model | author=McCall, Michael | publisher=No Depression | date=September–October 2003 | url-status=dead | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120929170603/http://archives.nodepression.com/2003/09/this-years-model/ | archive-date=2012-09-29 }}</ref> The album found a home on Capitol Records and was released in September 2003. The critics gave her high marks; AllMusic's Thom Jurek wrote, "There is no identity crisis here, just the indelible mark of a mature, intense, always engaging artist."<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/r651182 | title=Identity Crisis > Overview | author=Jurek, Thom | website=[[AllMusic]] | access-date=2023-07-08 | archive-date=2023-07-08 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230708022320/https://www.allmusic.com/album/identity-crisis-mw0000314253 | url-status=live }}</ref> ''[[Suit Yourself]]'' (2005) also received praise from critics. However, neither record was commercially successful.

===Later career===
[[File:Shelby Lynne 2014.jpg|thumb|Lynne performing in 2014]]
Her album ''[[Just a Little Lovin' (Shelby Lynne album)|Just a Little Lovin']]'', released in early 2008 by Lost Highway Records, paid tribute to the late British singer [[Dusty Springfield]]. The producer was [[Phil Ramone]], who had worked with Springfield on "[[The Look of Love (1967 song)|The Look of Love]]". ''Just A Little Lovin''' became the highest charting album of Lynne's career, reaching number 41 on the ''Billboard'' 200. In a review for ''Entertainment Weekly'', Marc Weingarten wrote that the album "is a stark reminder of Lynne's empathetic skill as an interpreter".<ref>{{cite magazine | url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20166944_20166960_20175495,00.html | archive-url=https://archive.today/20130123010011/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20166944_20166960_20175495,00.html | url-status=dead | archive-date=January 23, 2013 | title=Just a Little Lovin' | author=Weingarten, Marc| magazine=Entertainment Weekly | date=February 1, 2008}}</ref> The sparse production and extremely well recorded nature of the album, combined with its song selection have made this album a favorite audiophile "demo" recording, and as a result the album was reissued on audiophile-grade 200g vinyl as well as [[Super Audio CD|SACD]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://musicangle.com/feat.php?id=198 | title=" Just a Little Lovin' " Finally Gets Some | author=Marc, Andrei | publisher="Michael Fremer's Music Angle" | date=March 1, 2012 | access-date=May 8, 2012 | archive-date=May 9, 2012 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120509155225/http://musicangle.com/feat.php?id=198 | url-status=live }}</ref>

Following a dispute with Lost Highway, Lynne started her own label, called Everso Records. "I plan on taking advantage of my freedom and working hard and putting out a lot of records," she said in an interview.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/958499/shelby-lynne-plots-own-course-with-tears | title=Shelby Lynne Plots Own Course With 'Tears' | author=Graff, Gary | magazine=Billboard.com | date=April 23, 2010}}</ref> The first release was her album ''[[Tears, Lies and Alibis]]'' (2010). She followed up later that year with the holiday album ''Merry Christmas'', featuring such classics as "Christmas Time Is Here" and "O Holy Night". The third and most recent release is ''Revelation Road'' (2011), on which she played all the instruments.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=http://www.popmatters.com/pm/review/148772-shelby-lynne-revelation-road/ | title=Shelby Lynne: Revelation Road | author=Horowitz, Steve | magazine=PopMatters | date=October 20, 2011}}</ref>

On August 18, 2017, Lynne released a collaborative record with her sister [[Allison Moorer]] titled ''[[Not Dark Yet (album)|Not Dark Yet]]''. Produced by British folk singer [[Teddy Thompson]], it features covers of songs by [[Merle Haggard]], [[Bob Dylan]], [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]] and [[The Killers]] as well as an original recording.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1781782/shelby-lynne-and-allison-moorers-not-dark-yet-arrives-aug-18/|title=Shelby Lynne and Allison Moorer's Not Dark Yet Arrives Aug. 18|access-date=2017-05-27|archive-date=2017-05-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170525224318/http://www.cmt.com/news/1781782/shelby-lynne-and-allison-moorers-not-dark-yet-arrives-aug-18/|url-status=dead}}</ref>

===Additional projects===
Lynne performed the [[John Lennon]] song "Mother" at ''[[Come Together: A Night for John Lennon's Words and Music]]'' in October 2001 and at Theatre Within's 30th annual Lennon tribute in November 2010.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music/2010/11/15/2010-11-15_john_lennon_concert_brings_out_cyndi_lauper_patti_smith_aimee_mann_for_30th_year.html | title=John Lennon concert brings out Cyndi Lauper, Patti Smith, Aimee Mann for 30th year at Beacon Theater | author=Farber, Jim | newspaper=NY Daily News | date=November 15, 2010 | access-date=2010-12-04 | archive-date=2010-11-18 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101118064938/http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music/2010/11/15/2010-11-15_john_lennon_concert_brings_out_cyndi_lauper_patti_smith_aimee_mann_for_30th_year.html | url-status=live }}</ref>

She has worked professionally with her sister, Allison Moorer. On Moorer's live album ''Show'', released in 2003, Lynne performed three duets with her sister. Lynne wrote "She Knows Where She Goes", one of the songs featured on Moorer's 2008 album ''[[Mockingbird (Allison Moorer album)|Mockingbird]]''. The two sisters performed five concerts together during what they called the Side by Side tour. The concerts took place from October through December 2010 in San Francisco, New York, Virginia, and Alabama.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=4490 | title=Lynne, Moorer tour together for first time | magazine=Country Standard Time}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://blog.al.com/entertainment-press-register/2010/12/lynne_moorer_take_saenger_stag.html | title=Lynne, Moorer take Saenger stage 'side by side' at last | author=Specker, Lawrence F. | newspaper=Mobile Press-Register | date=December 4, 2010 | access-date=December 6, 2010 | archive-date=December 1, 2011 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111201052714/http://blog.al.com/entertainment-press-register/2010/12/lynne_moorer_take_saenger_stag.html | url-status=live }}</ref>

In 2002, she sang a duet with [[Raul Malo]] on his first solo album, ''Today''. The song is titled "Takes Two To Tango". In 2004, Lynne was featured in a duet version of [[alternative rock]] band [[Live (band)|Live]]'s song "Run Away." This rendition can be found on the band's greatest hits compilation ''[[Awake: The Best of Live]]''. Also in 2004, she sang a duet entitled "Can't Go Back Home", on Tony Joe White's album ''The Heroines''. In 2007, she performed background vocals on [[Marc Cohn]]'s fourth album, ''[[Join the Parade]]''. She contributed to ''Forever Cool'', a 2007 album from Capitol/EMI featuring contemporary artists in duets with the late [[Dean Martin]]. Alongside [[Big Bad Voodoo Daddy]], Lynne performed a duet of one of Martin's best-known tunes, "You're Nobody 'Til Somebody Loves You".

She also joined the 9th, 10th, 11th, 12th and, in 2015, the 14th annual Independent Music Awards judging panel, to assist independent musicians' careers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima_new/imajudges2010.asp|title=Independent Music Awards - 9th Annual Judges|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001005627/http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima_new/imajudges2010.asp|archive-date=2011-10-01}}</ref>

Lynne has taken on a few acting roles. "She expressed interest about working in film back in the January 1992 issue of ''Modern Screen's Country Music'' when we spoke for a story I teased on the cover ('Shelby Lynne: Is Hollywood Beckoning?') after her appearance in Willie Nelson's ''Another Pair of Aces'' TV-movie with Kris Kristofferson. 'It was hardly an acting role,' she said at the time. 'I played myself. I didn't even have any dialogue. Willie's a crook gone good. Kris is the sheriff and I'm a saloon singer. I sang two songs. One they played while Kris was makin' love. So, so much for my big acting career!{{'"}}<ref>{{Cite web |title=The sisterly significance of Allison Moorer and Shelby Lynne {{!}} Goldmine Magazine: Record Collector & Music Memorabilia |url=https://www.goldminemag.com/.amp/interviews/the-sisterly-significance-of-allison-moorer-and-shelby-lynne |access-date=2022-03-02 |website=www.goldminemag.com |date=18 May 2020 |archive-date=2022-03-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220302064017/https://www.goldminemag.com/.amp/interviews/the-sisterly-significance-of-allison-moorer-and-shelby-lynne |url-status=live }}</ref> She portrayed [[Johnny Cash]]'s mother Carrie in the 2005 film ''[[Walk the Line]]''. She appeared in a 2009 episode of the [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]] drama series ''[[Army Wives]]'' as a country singer trying to reunite with her son. She played herself in an episode of the [[Starz (TV channel)|Starz]] comedy series ''[[Head Case]]''.

She was featured in Live From Daryl's House with [[Daryl Hall]] in a "delta blues-meets-Philly soul" throwdown.  The show aired on Viacom's [[Palladia]] music channel on December 15, 2012.

==Personal life==
Lynne is not married and does not have children.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Farber |first=Jim |date=2017-08-13 |title=Shelby Lynne and Allison Moorer as Sisters With a Painful Bond |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/13/arts/music/shelby-lynne-allison-moorer-not-dark-yet.html |access-date=2023-03-29 |issn=0362-4331 |archive-date=2023-03-29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230329174921/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/13/arts/music/shelby-lynne-allison-moorer-not-dark-yet.html |url-status=live }}</ref> Although she has publicly disclosed that she is gay, Lynne has stated she intends to keep her life private outside of music.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Shulman |first=Randy |date=2018-07-19 |title=Shelby Lynne on Trump: "As an American, red-blooded, flag-waving, bonafide Dixie dyke, I'm appalled" |url=https://www.metroweekly.com/2018/07/shelby-lynne-on-trump-as-an-american-red-blooded-flag-waving-bonafide-dixie-dyke-im-appalled/ |access-date=2023-03-29 |website=Metro Weekly |language=en-US |archive-date=2023-03-29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230329174923/https://www.metroweekly.com/2018/07/shelby-lynne-on-trump-as-an-american-red-blooded-flag-waving-bonafide-dixie-dyke-im-appalled/ |url-status=live }}</ref>
